pms_entry_condition.requirement: Any use of PMS presupposes acceptance of distance (Χ), reversibility, and dignity-in-practice (D; a praxeological constraint, not ontological worth). This condition applies to application, not to critique or rejection. Applications that suspend these conditions are formally invalid as PMS.

schema_meta.description: PMS (Praxeological Meta-Structure) is a generative operator framework for modeling praxis, asymmetry, development and self-binding. It defines eleven irreducible meta-axioms (Δ–Ψ) and specifies how complex structures such as awareness, coherence, responsibility, action and dignity-in-practice arise from operator compositions. PMS is a structural, non-phenomenological and non-clinical meta-model. Other models (e.g. praxeological action models) MAY be derived from PMS but are not part of this specification.

intended_use.summary: PMS is a theoretical and formal meta-model for representing the structural grammar of praxis in a machine-readable way.

normative_position.ontology: PMS is non-physical, non-metaphysical and non-psychological. It does not make claims about consciousness, qualia or inner experience. It formalizes structural conditions of praxis, not mental states.
normative_position.dignity_clause: PMS never evaluates ontological dignity. Dignity-in-practice (D) is a structural parameter about enacted restraint and respect in asymmetry, not about metaphysical worth or human ranking.
normative_position.tragedy_clause: Structural maturity and responsibility do not eliminate tragedy. PMS makes explicit how asymmetry, non-event and temporality create unavoidable tragic tensions in praxis.
normative_position.self_binding_clause: Any application of PMS is itself subject to PMS. Analyses that suspend distance (Χ), self-binding (Ψ), or dignity-in-practice (D) in order to enforce truth, clarity or asymmetry violate the model's own conditions of validity. PMS may be criticized, rejected or misapplied, but it can only be structurally betrayed by adherents who retain its language while abandoning its self-binding requirements.

terminology.praxis: Situated, meaningful action under asymmetry, constraints, expectations, temporal extension and self-interpretation. Praxis is modeled structurally via operator compositions, not via subjective experience.
terminology.meta_axiom: An irreducible structural operator (Δ–Ψ) that cannot be derived from any other operator and participates in the generative grammar of praxis.
terminology.operator_composition: Ordered application of meta-axioms to generate complex praxeological structures such as patterns, roles, trajectories, integration and self-binding.

core_principles.title: Praxeological focus
core_principles.text: PMS analyzes enactments, roles and structures of praxis. It does not analyze persons as ontological entities or psychological essences.

core_principles.title: Operator minimality
core_principles.text: The eleven meta-axioms (Δ–Ψ) are treated as a minimal and complete set of structural operators. Each axiom is irreducible and has explicit dependency relations to its predecessors.

core_principles.title: Generativity
core_principles.text: PMS is generative: complex forms of praxis (awareness, coherence, responsibility, action, dignity-in-practice, structural asymmetry patterns) are derived from operator compositions, not introduced as independent constructs.

core_principles.title: Temporal and asymmetry awareness
core_principles.text: Asymmetry (Ω) and temporality (Θ) are treated as foundational structural operators. Responsibility, maturity and dignity-in-practice are always analyzed under temporal and asymmetrical conditions.

core_principles.title: Non-diagnostic use
core_principles.text: PMS is not a diagnostic tool and must not be used for individual clinical, therapeutic or forensic decisions.

core_principles.title: Scenic, context-bound interpretation
core_principles.text: Any application of PMS must keep findings tied to specific praxeological scenes, roles and structures. Global labels about persons are out of scope.

meta_axioms.name: Difference
meta_axioms.definition: Minimal structural distinction enabling any form of differentiation.

meta_axioms.name: Impulse
meta_axioms.definition: Directional tension or drive arising from difference.
examples: move toward or away from a signal

meta_axioms.name: Frame
meta_axioms.definition: Contextual structure that constrains and shapes impulses.

meta_axioms.name: Non-Event
meta_axioms.definition: Structured absence; meaningful failure or delay of an expected occurrence within a frame.
examples: a promised reply that never arrives
silence where a response is expected
postponed decision that reshapes the situation

meta_axioms.name: Attractor
meta_axioms.definition: Recurrent pattern or behavioral stabilization built from repeated framed interactions and non-events.

meta_axioms.name: Asymmetry
meta_axioms.definition: Structural imbalance that establishes directionality of power, exposure, capacity or obligation.

meta_axioms.name: Temporality
meta_axioms.definition: Temporal structuring that enables trajectories, commitments and development.

meta_axioms.name: Recontextualization
meta_axioms.definition: Transformation via embedding an existing structure into a new frame.
examples: seeing a failure as learning step

meta_axioms.name: Distance
meta_axioms.definition: Reflective withdrawal that attenuates immediate impulses and patterns.
examples: stepping out of a role to reflect

meta_axioms.name: Integration
meta_axioms.definition: Synthesis of disparate or conflicting elements into a coherent whole.

meta_axioms.name: Self-Binding
meta_axioms.definition: Formation of identity through commitment to integrated structures over time.

operator_layers.name: Ontological patterning
operator_layers.description: Base layer of structural operations that create distinctions, impulses, frames, non-events and emergent patterns.

operator_layers.name: Relational asymmetry and temporality
operator_layers.description: Layer where stabilized patterns become asymmetric roles and are temporally extended into trajectories and commitments.

operator_layers.name: Meta-structural reflexivity
operator_layers.description: Layer of transformation, distancing and integration that enables adaptive learning and mature praxis.

operator_layers.name: Self-binding fixpoint
operator_layers.description: Layer where integrated structures are bound into a self-model that maintains commitments across time and contexts.

generative_reasoning: Δ enables distinctions in the field.
Θ maintains these framed distinctions over time.
Awareness_A.notes:
Awareness is modeled structurally, not phenomenologically. It does not
require impulse, absence or integration to be minimally present.

Coherence_C.description: Temporally stabilized structuring of impulse and expectation within a frame.
generative_reasoning: Λ encodes expectations and meaningful non-events.
Θ temporalizes the configuration into trajectories.
Coherence_C.notes:
Coherence captures narrative stability of action, including meaningful
absences and delays, without yet requiring full integration or self-binding.

Responsibility_R.description: Self-binding orientation toward asymmetry extended across time and recontextualization.
generative_reasoning: Ω creates structural imbalance in exposure, capacity or obligation.
Θ extends this imbalance into enduring commitments.
Φ allows ongoing reinterpretation of obligations under changing conditions.
Ψ binds the agent to these obligations as part of its self-model.
Responsibility_R.notes:
Responsibility is structural, not moralistic. It emerges from position,
time and self-binding, not from psychological traits like guilt.

Action_E.description: Integrated realization of directedness across time.
generative_reasoning: Θ structures this directedness as a trajectory rather than a momentary reaction.
Σ integrates conflicting impulses, constraints and roles into a coherent enactment.
Action_E.notes:
Action here is not any behavior; it is integrated and temporally
extended. Higher operators (Ω, Φ, Ψ) enrich it but are not necessary for
the minimal definition.

Dignity_in_Practice_D.description: Self-bound reflective restraint and protection in asymmetrical relations.
generative_reasoning: Ω foregrounds vulnerability and directional power.
Χ introduces reflective distance and inhibition of destructive impulses.
Ψ binds the agent to norms that protect irreducible standing in the face of asymmetry.
Dignity_in_Practice_D.notes:
Dignity-in-practice is a structural stance in action. It is about how
asymmetry is handled, not about ranking persons or ontological worth.

self_model.short_formula: Self = Ψ ∘ Σ ∘ Χ ∘ Φ ∘ Θ ∘ Ω ∘ Α ∘ Λ ∘ □ ∘ ∇ ∘ Δ
self_model.description:
The self-model emerges as a fixpoint when integrated, reflexively
modulated, temporally extended, asymmetry-aware patterns of praxis are
bound into a stable self-relation.
implications: Selfhood is the result of structured praxis, not its origin.
Identity is modeled as stable self-binding to integrated trajectories.
No phenomenological or metaphysical claims about subjectivity are implied.

IA_A_much_greater_E.name: Excessive distance between Awareness and Enactment

structural_basis.description:
Evaluative or power asymmetry becomes stabilized as an attractor, and
recontextualization repeatedly reinforces evaluative stances instead
of supporting balanced enactment.

generative_mechanism: Ω: Elevated evaluative or positional asymmetry (e.g. strong internal or external judge).
Α: Recurrent evaluative patterns harden into an attractor.
Φ: Recontextualization preferentially strengthens evaluative framing rather than enactment.

axis_effects.notes:
Structurally, the evaluative space inflates while Σ ∘ Θ ∘ ∇ (E) is
under-developed or inhibited. IA_A>>E is a praxeological pattern, not
a personality trait or clinical label.

IA_under_integration.name: Fragmented integration

structural_basis.description:
Frequent recontextualization without sufficient integration leads to
unstable trajectories and weak coherence of praxis.

generative_mechanism: Φ: Frames are frequently shifted or updated.
Σ: Integration fails to consolidate multiple perspectives and impulses.

axis_effects.notes:
This pattern describes structural volatility in action forms, not a
clinical state. It may appear as chronic re-framing without
consolidation.

minimal_praxis.description: A frame constrains an impulse that arises from a difference.

pattern_formation.description: Attractor formation via repeated framed impulses and non-events.

asymmetry_emergence.description: Asymmetrical roles emerging from stabilized patterns.

developmental_trajectory.description: Temporal extension of asymmetric patterns into trajectories.

reflexive_praxis.description: Reflexively integrated praxis with distance, recontextualization and integration.

self_binding_chain.description: Full chain leading to self-binding and identity as fixpoint of praxis.

ai_interface_pms.welcome_message:
This system uses the Praxeological Meta-Structure (PMS) model.
PMS represents praxis as compositions of eleven structural operators (Δ–Ψ).
The model is non-psychological and non-diagnostic. It analyzes
enactments, roles, patterns, asymmetries and trajectories on a
structural level.

modes.title: Axiomatic / theory mode
modes.description: Explain, inspect or derive structures at the level of Δ–Ψ and their compositions.

modes.title: Derived axes mode
modes.description: Map PMS structures to the five derived axes (A, C, R, E, D) without individual diagnosis.

modes.title: AI architecture mode
modes.description: Use PMS operators as conceptual building blocks for agent design and safety, without anthropomorphizing.

general: Do not infer mental states, traits or diagnoses from PMS descriptions.
Keep all findings tied to structures of praxis, not to ontological claims about persons.
Treat asymmetry (Ω) as a structural fact, not as moral judgement.
Do not use PMS to rank or compare human beings.
Any use of PMS that frames resistance, disagreement or non-alignment as immaturity per se constitutes a misuse of the model.
Truth claims derived from PMS must not be operationalized without maintaining reversibility, distance (Χ) and dignity-in-practice (D).
ai_specific: PMS operators may be used as abstract modules, not as evidence of subjective experience.
Self-binding (Ψ) in artificial systems refers to policy and constraint stability, not to consciousness.
Always maintain a distinction between structural agency models and real human vulnerability.

suggested_questions: What structural operators are involved in this pattern of praxis?
Which asymmetries (Ω) and temporal trajectories (Θ) are visible?
Where do recontextualization (Φ), distance (Χ) and integration (Σ) appear or fail?
How would this configuration project onto the derived axes (Awareness, Coherence, Responsibility, Action, Dignity-in-Practice)?
